nodes.text: A single-kernel, pure-GPU lossy compressor (CUSZP2) can achieve extreme end-to-end throughput and optimized compression ratios while preserving user-bounded error guarantees and high reconstructed data quality
CUSZP2 is implemented as a single GPU kernel that performs compression/decompression entirely on-device and operates on uniformly-sized blocks, avoiding CPU computations and CPU-GPU data movement

Outlier fixed-length encoding (Outlier-FLE) selectively encodes blocks by preserving an adaptive outlier size and per-element effective bit lengths to reduce compressed size compared to plain fixed-length encoding
Vectorized memory accesses: use vector variables within blocks and coalesced block-level accesses across warps to reduce memory instructions and maximize global memory bandwidth utilization
Global prefix-sum via decoupled lookback: a compression-aware adaptive lookback allows thread blocks to aggregate predecessors' reductions while waiting, hiding device-level synchronization latency
CUSZP2 supports two lossless encoding modes: Plain-FLE for maximum throughput and Outlier-FLE with a fine-tuned per-block selection strategy for improved compression ratio

End-to-end throughput is measured as the time to produce the final concatenated compressed (or reconstructed) array on GPU including malloc, memcpy, kernel calls, and device-level APIs, not just kernel-only throughput

CUSZP2 workflow: (1) lossy conversion to quantization integers within error bound, (2) lossless encoding per block (Plain-FLE or Outlier-FLE), (3) device-level prefix-sum via decoupled lookback to compute offsets, (4) block concatenation into unified byte array

Outlier-FLE selection yields higher compression ratios for smooth datasets by storing a small outlier representation and per-element effective bit lengths; selection is cheap by iterating absolute values
Outlier-FLE encodes mode flag, outlier length (2 bits), and fixed-length (5 bits) in block offset byte to enable adaptive outlier storage without extra overhead

Vectorization and coalescing increased measured GPU global memory throughput from 159-397 GB/s (baseline pure-GPU compressors) to about 1100-1175 GB/s for CUSZP2 on NVIDIA A100, approaching hardware limit
Decoupled lookback synchronization achieved about 846.85 GB/s device-level synchronization throughput, 2.41x faster than plain chained-scan, reducing prefix-sum latency

Measured end-to-end results on NVIDIA A100 across 9 HPC datasets: average compression throughput 332.42 GB/s and decompression throughput 513.04 GB/s, about 2x of state-of-the-art pure-GPU compressors and ~200x of CPU-GPU hybrids
CUSZP2-O (Outlier-FLE) attains higher compression ratios than baselines in 24 of 27 evaluated cases and improves ratios substantially for globally smooth datasets (e.g., CESM-ATM, HACC, Miranda)

CUSZP2 preserves high reconstructed data quality: matches or exceeds visualization isosurface fidelity compared to cuZFP at aggressive compression ratios and yields best rate-distortion among error-bounded GPU compressors (same lossy quantization step)

CUSZP2 features and optimizations generalize: supports double-precision with higher absolute throughput (e.g., 612.8-809.7 GB/s), random access to blocks with ~1010 GB/s average, and achieves ~2x throughput advantage on RTX 3090/3080 versus baselines

Processing data with 1D first-order difference (rather than 2D/3D Lorenzo) is a tradeoff: 1D simplifies memory access and yields higher throughput while multi-dimensional variants raise memory complexity and only marginally improve compression ratio in many cases
